Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Petitioner respectfully requests a modification of the existing custody order to provide for overnight visitation with the Respondent at his residence.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 355 (1996).proposition: The Petitioner respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grants the requested modification to the existing custody order in the best interests of the minor child, Lucas Smith.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 355 (1996).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of an existing child custody order based on the best interests of a minor child. Custody of Vaughn, as excerpted here, is actually a criminal case involving a murder conviction and felony-murder instructions, not a probate/family law custody dispute. The opinion does not discuss custody standards, best-interests analysis, or modification of custody orders, so it cannot support the stated custody proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 355 (1996).relevant_excerpt: A jury convicted the defendant of murder in the first degree by reason of felony-murder. The defendant was also convicted of armed robbery. On appeal, he contends that the trial judge committed error when he failed to: (1) give a requested instruction on assault and battery; (2) give an instruction on involuntary manslaughter; and (3) supplement the given instruction on murder in the second degree.

Wick v. Wick, 443 Mass. 177 (2005).proposition: The Petitioner respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grants the requested modification to the existing custody order in the best interests of the minor child, Lucas Smith.
Wick v. Wick, 443 Mass. 177 (2005).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a request for modification of a child custody order based on the best interests of a minor child. Wick v. Wick, 443 Mass. 177 (2005), addresses criminal law issues involving a surety’s authority to apprehend and detain a bail principal, not family law, custody, or best-interests standards. The case thus provides no authority for the requested custody modification and is being cited out of context for that proposition.
Wick v. Wick, 443 Mass. 177 (2005).relevant_excerpt: “To answer Question 1, we must resolve two related questions. First, do a surety and his agents have the lawful authority to apprehend, detain, and deliver the principal to the court house? … [A] surety and his agents may use only such force as is reasonable in the circumstances to apprehend, detain, and deliver the principal to the court house….”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: The Petitioner respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grants the requested modification to the existing custody order in the best interests of the minor child, Lucas Smith.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The case concerns the constitutionality and interpretation of a Massachusetts grandparent-visitation statute and the standards (best interests plus significant harm) for third-party visitation over a fit parent’s objection. It does not involve or decide a petition to modify an existing custody order between parents, nor does it discuss the general standard for modification of custody. While it uses a best-interests framework in the grandparent-visitation context, it provides no authority for a generic request that a court modify a custody order in a child’s best interests.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation. This standard has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation and other issues relating to child welfare. The statute, however, uses the standard in a new context… To accord with due process, an evaluation of the best interests of the child under the statute requires that a parental decision concerning grandparent visitation be given presumptive validity.”

Perlitz v. Perlitz, 422 Mass. 744 (1996).proposition: Since the issuance of the original custody Order, significant changes have occurred that warrant a modification of the custody arrangement.
Perlitz v. Perlitz, 422 Mass. 744 (1996).case_name: Rate Setting Commission v. Baystate Medical Center
Perlitz v. Perlitz, 422 Mass. 744 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is not a custody or domestic relations case and does not concern modification of a custody order or the standard for such modification. It deals with Medicaid reimbursement rate-setting, administrative jurisdiction, and evidentiary rulings. Therefore, it does not address whether significant changes since an original custody order warrant modification, and cannot support that proposition.

Bains v. Bains, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 313 (2.raw_text: Bains v. Bains, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 313 (2011)
Bains v. Bains, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 313 (2.proposition: Lucas Smith is now 8 years old, attends school full-time, and has expressed a strong desire for overnight stays at his father's residence.
Bains v. Bains, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 313 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the age, schooling, and custodial/visitation preferences of a specific child, Lucas Smith. The cited opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about online dissemination of obscene material and enticement of a minor, and it does not mention Lucas Smith, custody, visitation, or any child’s wishes about overnight stays. Therefore, it provides no legal or factual support for the asserted proposition.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Lucas Smith is now 8 years old, attends school full-time, and has expressed a strong desire for overnight stays at his father's residence.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the current personal circumstances and subjective wishes of a specific child, Lucas Smith, regarding overnight visitation with his father. Rolde v. Rolde is a Massachusetts appellate decision about divorce, division of marital assets, and custody/visitation arrangements between Dr. Alexandra and Dr. Edward Rolde’s children; it does not mention Lucas Smith, his age, school attendance, or any expressed desire for overnight stays. The case provides general principles on custody and visitation but does not establish or affirm the factual proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The order provided that the children would spend six weeks in the summer, one evening a week, alternate weekends and alternate holidays with their father. Following an eight-day trial the judge awarded sole custody of the children to the wife, limited Edward’s visitation rights to two weeks in the summer, and eliminated evening visitation during the alternate weeks on which there is weekend visitation; the holiday schedule remained the same.”

Strittmatter v. Strittmatter, 62 Mass.Ap.proposition: The proposed modification seeks to amend the current custody arrangement to allow for alternating weekends and one weekday overnight visit per week, taking into consideration Lucas's school schedule and personal preferences.
Strittmatter v. Strittmatter, 62 Mass.Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns workers’ compensation for an injury allegedly caused by an employer-sponsored flu shot and the admissibility of expert medical causation testimony. It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, visitation schedules, or any modification of custody arrangements, much less alternating weekends and weekday overnights tied to a child’s school schedule or preferences. Therefore, it provides no authority for the stated custody/visitation proposition.
Strittmatter v. Strittmatter, 62 Mass.Ap.relevant_excerpt: “This is an appeal from a judgment entered by a single justice of this court affirming a decision of the Department of Industrial Accidents reviewing board (reviewing board), which in turn affirmed the decision of an administrative judge to admit in evidence certain medical opinion testimony, and reversed the decision of a second administrative judge who had concluded that the employee had failed to prove that her injury arose out of and in the course of her employment.”

Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).proposition: Since the issuance of the original custody Order, significant changes have occurred that warrant a modification of the custody arrangement.
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Adams v. Adams concerns appellate impoundment of records and the court’s authority to vacate an impoundment order on its own initiative. It does not discuss child custody, standards for modification of custody, or any requirement of a material or significant change in circumstances. Therefore, this citation does not support the proposition about changed circumstances warranting modification of a custody order.
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).relevant_excerpt: Given the court’s ruling, it may make sense for our rules committee to reexamine the rule on impounded appeals, S.J.C. Rule 1:15. I am concerned that the rule as it is currently written may give parties and nonparties who have obtained impoundment orders in the trial court a false sense of assurance that the impoundment will be honored by the appellate court if it is not being challenged. Perhaps the rule should be changed to require one who has obtained an impoundment order in the trial court to apply anew to the appellate court for impoundment of the appeal.

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Both the Petitioner and the Respondent acknowledge the necessity of modifying the custody arrangement to better serve Lucas's best interests as he has grown and his circumstances have evolved.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody only in terms of the judge’s findings and her modification of the mechanism for future custody changes. It does not state that both parents acknowledge the necessity of modifying the custody arrangement due to the child’s growth or evolving circumstances; rather, it notes that both parents agreed to try joint legal custody with a mediator and a specific caveat about future changes. That is an agreement on a particular arrangement, not a mutual acknowledgment of a need for modification based on changed circumstances over time.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The judge was presented with an alternative arrangement, agreed to by both the husband and the wife, whereby, with the help of a mediator, they would have the opportunity to try joint legal custody, with the caveat that should this arrangement not work out peaceably, either party could move for a hearing (with the understanding that custody then would most likely be given solely to the husband).”
